0.00.text:
Translator: Denise RQ
Reviewer: Lena Clemente

4.80.text: At age 22, I was completely immersed

8.96.text: in this world of spying the Pentagon

15.72.text:
Everything that I did
in my adolescent life

19.33.text: was to prepare me for my fantasy career.

22.71.text: But I'm here, just a few years later,

25.58.text:
as a career coach
to hundreds of millennials.

30.00.text: So how and why does this happen?

32.95.text: That's exactly what people asked me

35.19.text: when I quit my job in Washington, DC,

38.20.text:
and booked a one-way trip
home to Los Angeles.

41.47.text:
And I tell people
that my answer is simple:

44.87.text: political science is what I love,

48.50.text: but career coaching is what I am.

52.45.text:
This dance that we all do
between finding work that we love

57.22.text:
and finding work
that aligns with who we are

59.89.text: is what I want to talk about today.

62.83.text:
So I remember, four years ago living in DC
and going through my quarter life crisis,

67.23.text:
and I was just chaotic,
desperate for answers,

72.20.text: lots of pints of ice cream;

73.96.text:
and I [also] remember
hiring a career coach,

77.08.text: and this fundamentally changed my life.

79.71.text: And in the process, I realized

81.37.text:
that there were three key questions
that helped me unlock my authentic career.

86.44.text: And I want to share them with you today.

88.92.text: The first question is: what am I good at?

94.27.text:
Second question is:
what do people tell me I'm good at?

99.26.text:
And the final question: ask yourself,
"What's holding me back?"

106.73.text:
at the foundation
of my career coaching practice.

110.58.text: So, let's start with what am I good at.

113.54.text:
We're told early
that we need to find our passion.

116.85.text:
When we get to college,
we need to pick a major or a passion,

120.82.text: way before we've given much thought

122.82.text:
to who we want to be
in our careers and in our lives.

127.01.text:
As a result, some of you here
have majors that fascinate you.

130.99.text:
But there are others
who simply picked the topics

133.42.text:
so you could get your bachelor's degree
out of the way and move on with your life.

139.83.text:
Your interest in a subject
does not guarantee

143.54.text: your success in a career with it.

146.02.text: And that's why I'm here to remind you

148.75.text:
to do something that you are
not just what you love.

154.47.text:
I remember four years ago getting
a phone call from a defense contractor

157.91.text:
that I was hired to run a program
for the Pentagon.

160.67.text: I was ecstatic, and then I panicked.

164.05.text:
I just remember, you know,
reading about this program

166.99.text:
that prepared senior government officials
to deploy to Afghanistan

171.12.text: where they would then serve as advisers

173.49.text:
to high-level officials
in the Afghan government.

176.95.text: As the only woman in the room,

178.55.text:
and definitely the youngest
employee in my firm,

181.61.text: I fell like I had the world to prove.

185.21.text:
So, like many of you probably understand,
my job took over my life.

190.49.text:
I spent ten-to-15-hour days
in Washington, DC,

194.04.text:
and a lot of my weekends ended up
on military bases in the Midwest,

198.61.text:
these training programs
and weapons qualifications.

201.54.text:
And I'll never forget
one particular Sunday:

204.67.text: one of the advisers called me over,

206.86.text: and in the midst of our discussion,

208.73.text:
he asked me if I could hold his gun,
so he could tie a shoe.

215.22.text:
I realized without hesitation
as I threw my hand out

218.00.text:
that this was going to be
the first time I ever held a gun!

222.44.text: This gun just dropped cold in my hand,

224.90.text:
and I just remember these chills
going down my spine.

229.02.text:
I felt like I was holding
death in my hands.

233.91.text: So here is the great question.

235.47.text:
How was I going to be a spy
if I couldn't really hold a gun?

242.11.text: That set me into a tailspin,

243.73.text:
because I remember feeling
like my career, my passion, my identity

247.75.text: were all in conflict with one another.

249.94.text: And I felt so alone, but guess what?

254.72.text:
Seventy five percent of the US population,
according to Reuters,

260.12.text:
is hiding some part
of their identity at work.

263.66.text: I wasn't the exception, I was the rule.

266.77.text: In order for me to succeed

268.48.text:
in these National Security niche
that I cared so much about,

273.57.text:
my feelings, my fears, my insecurities,
and probably my identity itself

281.26.text: I'd say ten pints of ice cream

283.21.text:
and at least 30 episodes
of "Sex in the City" later,

286.72.text:
I got off the couch, and I realized
it's time to ask for help.

290.15.text: And that was when I hired my career coach.

293.14.text:
And in our work together, I realized
how important it is for all of us

296.88.text:
to tune out the social pressure
to find what we love

301.23.text:
and tune in to something more significant
for your career and your life:

308.91.text:
It's never too late,
and it's never too early

311.44.text: for you to ask for help.

315.20.text: My second question for you to ask yourself

317.35.text: is: what do people tell me I'm good at?

320.80.text: So some of you here may be thinking,

322.56.text:
"OK, Ashley, I don't really know
what I'm good at,

324.96.text: I don't know what my values are,"

327.96.text:
But take an inventory
of what people tell you you're good at.

331.57.text:
Do friends turn to you
for some sort of advice

334.33.text: that you seem to have down?

336.30.text:
Or do your professors
and colleagues praise

343.60.text:
Do people ever ask you to teach them
something that you seem to know well?

348.40.text:
These are the moments
that shed light on your natural talents,

351.66.text: and the work force needs them.

354.17.text: Often, I get clients ages 18 to 30,

356.99.text:
and they are all so worried
about finding their passion

360.39.text:
that they completely overlooked
their natural skills.

363.88.text:
I, for one, was so focused
on finding my passion

367.16.text:
that I completely overlooked
my natural talent for the job hunt.

372.35.text:
In the span of six weeks,
I went to 90 events,

378.12.text:
I had coffee with 200 people,
and I got three job offers.

385.03.text:
So, other than being
completely wired from all that coffee,

388.46.text:
I got phone calls from all these friends
who wanted advice on their careers,

395.07.text:
what our conversations
did for their lives.

399.75.text:
I had friends calling me telling me
that they figured out

402.63.text:
what they want to do
with their career path and their life.

406.06.text:
And a lot of them ended up
quitting their jobs,

408.30.text: which isn't my fault, I'm just saying.

413.00.text:
and I was loving the fact
that they would call me and tell me

415.89.text:
that my techniques
or our conversations empowered them

418.50.text:
to get raises at work
or get job offers after a stale job hunt.

422.74.text:
But more than being
empowered, I was clear.

425.98.text: I'm a coach. I'm a career coach.

430.00.text: I'm often the only person I know in a room

432.84.text:
who literally cannot get enough
of a good job hunt.

437.69.text:
On the way to finding my passion,
or job in my passion,

442.32.text:
I found something
so much more significant: who I am.

448.10.text:
Don't be so blinded by your passion
that you overlook who you are.

452.55.text: Those who pay attention will find it.

456.21.text:
My final question for you to ask yourself
is, "What's holding me back?"

461.53.text:
So this is the one that a lot of clients
come to me and go,

464.38.text: "Don't want to talk about that one!"

466.35.text:
And I'm just like,
"You know? Here's the thing.

468.87.text: We have up to 70,000 thoughts each day

473.16.text:
and up to 98% of your thoughts
are repeat offenders,

480.48.text:
Looks like we're all sitting
together on a thought carousel

483.45.text: just going around and around and around

489.25.text:
And so many of these thoughts
may be holding you back in your career,"

493.20.text:
and that's why I ask a lot of my clients
to keep a journal for two weeks,

497.34.text:
where they share with me
their fear-based thoughts.

500.73.text:
And guess what?
Everyone's thoughts are the same!

509.33.text: These words keep your career bar low,

511.69.text:
and they keep you
for striving less in your life,

514.14.text:
and if you simply pay attention
to these words, or your fears,

521.65.text:
for you to hang out with your fears,
or hang out with the crazy,

524.95.text: it's a whole another thing to live in it.

528.98.text:
If you open your emotional backpack,
and you question yourself,

534.19.text: you will unlock your authentic career.

538.73.text: Standing here with you at Berkeley today,

541.92.text:
I remember that voice in my head
at the Pentagon saying,

550.20.text:
And that's when these three questions
can save you when you're stuck,

553.75.text: and you don't know where else to go,

558.58.text: "What do people tell me I'm good at?,"

564.92.text: If you ask yourself these three questions,

567.00.text:
you will be able to do more
of what you are not just what you love.

571.86.text: Talk to people, talk to your friends,

574.41.text:
talk to your professors,
hire a career coach.

577.87.text: But don't be afraid to ask questions,

582.08.text:
you will be able to embrace
a career that waits for you.
